figures.description: Production possibility curve for Questions 2 and 3. The vertical axis shows quantity of good \(Y\) and the horizontal axis quantity of good \(X\). The curve is downward‑sloping and concave to the origin, joining the intercepts \((0, Y_{\max})\) and \((X_{\max}, 0)\). Grid marks on the \(X\)-axis at \(20, 40, 60, 80, 100\) units and on the \(Y\)-axis at \(20, 40, 60, 80\). At \(Y = 80\) the corresponding \(X\)-coordinate is approximately 20 units.

Demand–supply diagram for Question 14. Price \(P\) is on the vertical axis and quantity \(Q\) on the horizontal axis. An upward‑sloping supply curve \(S\) intersects the original demand curve \(D_0 D_0\) at \((Q_0, P_1)\). A new demand curve \(D_1 D_1\) lies to the right of \(D_0 D_0\), passing through a higher quantity \(Q_2\) at the same price \(P_1\), indicating an increase in demand.

Monopoly cost–revenue diagram for Questions 17 and 18. Vertical axis: price/cost; horizontal axis: output. A downward‑sloping demand curve labelled \(D = AR\) and a steeper marginal‑revenue curve \(MR\) are shown. The U‑shaped average total cost curve \(ATC\) lies above the upward‑sloping marginal‑cost curve \(MC\). Several horizontal price lines \(P_1, P_2, P_3, P_4\) intersect the demand curve at outputs \(W, X, Y, Z\).

Consumption function for Question 19. Horizontal axis: income \(Y\); vertical axis: consumption \(C\). A straight line from point \(R\) on the vertical axis to point \(T\) in the first quadrant represents \(C = a + bY\). Point \(P\) lies on the horizontal axis where a perpendicular up to the line meets it at \(T\). The marginal propensity to consume is the slope of the line, i.e. change in \(C\) over change in \(Y\).

Total‑, average‑ and marginal‑revenue table for Questions 20 and 21. Output \(Q\) (units) and total revenue \(TR\) (naira): \(Q=1, TR=20\); \(Q=2, TR=38\); \(Q=3, TR=54\); \(Q=4, TR=68\); \(Q=5, TR=80\). Average revenue \(AR = TR/Q\) and marginal revenue \(MR = \Delta TR / \Delta Q\) are tabulated alongside.

Output–time diagram for Question 47. The horizontal axis measures time and the vertical axis measures either output or unemployment rate. A smooth long‑run trend line slopes upward, while a wavy dotted line oscillates above and below it, representing cyclical fluctuations in economic activity and unemployment.

Income‑components table for Question 39. Items and their amounts in billion naira (\(\text{N}bn\)): (1) Wages and salaries: 380; (2) Profits and rents: 110; (3) Payments to foreigners on assets held in Nigeria: 10; (4) Income from foreign assets held by Nigerians resident abroad: 20; (5) Depreciation: 40. Used to compute net national income by the income approach.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: It is impossible to satisfy all human wants because

options.text: areas of fertile land are very limited
oceans and seas limit land space for farming

questions.explanation: The basic economic problem is **scarcity**: resources are limited relative to wants.

questions.question: The diagram in figure Econ1993_PPC_XY, showing the maximum possible combinations of commodities X and Y produced in Nigeria, is called the
questions.explanation: The curve represents the **production possibility frontier (PPF)** between goods X and Y.

questions.question: Using the same diagram (figure Econ1993_PPC_XY), how many units of good X are produced when 80 units of commodity Y are produced?
questions.explanation: At \(Q_Y = 80\) the point on the PPF corresponds approximately to \(Q_X = 20\) units.

questions.question: The main function of the price system is to

options.text: distribute resources equally among competing ends
ensure efficient allocation of resources in the economic system
allocate goods and services equally among citizens

questions.explanation: Through prices, resources are directed to their most valued uses, promoting **allocative efficiency**.

questions.question: A system in which the means of production is held in trust for the people by government is known as a
questions.explanation: Under **socialism**, the state owns and manages the major means of production on behalf of the people.

questions.question: The working population refers to

options.text: a population where the death rate is falling
the population within the 0–14 age group
the economically active segment of the population

questions.explanation: Working population is the **economically active group**, usually ages 15–64.

questions.question: Which of the following factors is NOT responsible for the rural–urban drift in Nigeria?

options.text: Declining fertility of rural farm lands
Higher living standards in urban areas

questions.explanation: Rural electrification **improves rural conditions** and tends to reduce, not increase, migration to cities.

questions.question: An accurate census is important to a country because it helps

options.text: to ensure equitable population redistribution relative to natural resources
in deciding on the creation of more local governments
in providing a sound basis for formulating development policy

questions.explanation: Reliable population data are essential as a **basis for planning and development policy**.

questions.question: If 502.75 million tonnes of grains are consumed annually by a population of 88.5 million people, the per capita grain consumption is
questions.explanation: Per capita consumption \(= 502.75 / 88.5 \approx 5.68\) tonnes.

questions.question: In the theory of production and cost, the average total cost of a firm is minimized when the marginal cost curve and the average total cost curve intersect at its
questions.explanation: The \(MC\) curve cuts \(ATC\) at the **minimum point** of \(ATC\).

questions.question: A firm faces diminishing returns when its
questions.explanation: Diminishing returns set in once **marginal product** (marginal output) begins to fall.

questions.question: If labour productivity in the cement industry is increasing as output of cement is expanded, then the amount of labour required per unit of output is
questions.explanation: If productivity (output per worker) rises, the **labour input per unit of output falls**—it is decreasing.

questions.question: If profit maximization is assumed to be the objective of a business enterprise, labour must be paid a wage rate equal to the

options.text: marginal revenue product of labour in the enterprise

questions.explanation: In competitive factor markets, firms hire labour up to where **wage = marginal revenue product of labour (MRP\_L)**.

questions.question: From the demand–supply diagram in figure Econ1993_DemandShift, the shift in the demand curve from \(D_0D_0\) to \(D_1D_1\) implies

options.text: a rise in the demand for the commodity
fluctuation in the demand for the commodity
a fall in the demand for the commodity
an equilibrium in the demand for the commodity

questions.explanation: The new curve \(D_1\) lies to the **right** of \(D_0\), indicating an increase in demand at every price.

questions.question: If the equilibrium price for a certain commodity is \(\text{N}120.00\) and the government fixes its price at \(\text{N}110.00\), the quantity supplied will be

options.text: the same as the equilibrium supply
a determinant of the market forces of equilibrium

questions.explanation: A price ceiling below equilibrium creates a **shortage**; suppliers now offer **less** than at the equilibrium price.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a certain commodity is less than unity, then

options.text: an increase in the price of the commodity will raise the total revenue of the producer
an increase in price leaves the total revenue unchanged
a decrease in price raises the total revenue of the supplier
a decrease in price leaves the total revenue constant

questions.explanation: For inelastic demand (\(|E_d|<1\)), price and total revenue move in the **same direction**.

questions.question: Using the monopoly cost–revenue diagram in figure Econ1993_Monopoly_MC_ATC, what is the lowest possible price the monopolist could charge and still break even without there being excess demand?
questions.explanation: Break‑even occurs where **price equals average total cost** on the demand curve. The exact price label cannot be read clearly from the scan; consult the original diagram or marking scheme.

questions.question: At equilibrium one of the distinctive features of monopoly compared with perfect competition is that in the former

options.text: price is always equal to marginal cost
supply is always equal to demand
price is always higher than marginal cost
there are always many buyers and many sellers

questions.explanation: A monopolist equates **MC and MR**, not MC and price; since \(P > MR\) on a downward‑sloping demand curve, we have **\(P > MC\)**.

questions.question: In the consumption–income diagram in figure Econ1993_MPC_Line, the marginal propensity to consume (MPC) is equal to
questions.explanation: MPC is the **slope** of the consumption function, i.e. \(\Delta C / \Delta Y\). From the triangle formed, this equals the vertical change divided by the horizontal change (e.g. \(RT / PT\)). The precise ratio given by the labelled segments is unclear in the scan.

questions.question: Using the revenue table in figure Econ1993_TR_AR_MR_Table, given an output of 3 units, the average revenue is
Using the same table, determine the marginal revenue if the total revenue is \(\text{N}80.00\).
questions.explanation: TR of \(80\) corresponds to \(Q = 5\). \(MR_5 = TR_5 - TR_4 = 80 - 68 = 12\).

questions.question: Which of the following functions does the wholesaler perform to save the retailer the burden of carrying large stock?
questions.explanation: Relevant functions: **I. Breaking bulk** and **II. Packing goods in smaller containers**, which reduce retailers’ stock‑holding needs.

questions.question: Production is said to be completed when

options.text: goods and services reach the consumers
prices of goods or services are determined
goods are sold to the wholesaler

questions.explanation: Economically, production is complete only when goods **reach and satisfy final consumers**.

questions.question: A debenture share entitles its holder to

options.text: participate in the annual general meeting of the company
receive a fixed interest on sums invested
have a representation on the Board of Directors

questions.explanation: Debenture holders are **creditors** and receive a fixed rate of interest.

questions.question: A public liability company is different from a private limited company because it

options.text: is registered with the Registrar of Companies
can raise capital of any size by way of loans
can sell shares in the Stock Exchange

questions.explanation: Only public limited companies can have their shares **traded on the stock exchange**.

questions.question: A modern corporation is owned by
questions.explanation: Ordinary shareholders are the **residual owners** of the company.

questions.question: Wheat grows best in
questions.explanation: Wheat is typically a **temperate‑climate** crop.

questions.question: On the basis of the contribution to employment, the most important economic sector in West Africa is
questions.explanation: Agriculture employs the **largest share of the labour force** in most West African countries.

questions.question: The most popularly adopted industrialization strategy in West Africa is
questions.explanation: Many West African countries initially pursued **import‑substitution industrialization**.

questions.question: One of the most important factors that should be considered in the location of an industry is
questions.explanation: Firms locate where **raw materials and markets** are easily accessible.

questions.question: Since the mid‑1980s, the most disturbing development in the industrial sector in Nigeria is
questions.explanation: Economic crises led to **very high levels of idle industrial capacity**.

questions.question: The money market is a financial market that specializes in the provision of
questions.explanation: Money markets deal in **short‑term funds and instruments** (e.g. treasury bills, call money).

questions.question: Which of the following programmes in the monetary sector is aimed at enhancing the banking habit of rural areas?

options.text: The deregulation of the banking system
The increase in the number of merchant banks

questions.explanation: Community banks were established specifically to **mobilize savings and extend banking services to rural communities**.

questions.question: If the sum of \(\text{N}80{,}000\) is deposited in a bank and the cash‑reserve ratio of the banking system is \(10\%\), calculate the total sum of credit that can be created from the deposit.
questions.explanation: Money multiplier \(k = 1/CR = 1/0.10 = 10\). Total credit \(= k \times 80{,}000 = 800{,}000\).

questions.question: Economic development is distinguishable from economic growth because the former

options.text: is not concerned with growth parameters
also includes an efficient distribution of economic growth
is an increase in the production of goods and services

questions.explanation: Development implies growth **plus structural and welfare improvements**, including a better distribution of income.

questions.question: Which of the following can be considered as being outside the objectives of public finance?

options.text: The allocation of resources to various sectors of the economy
The objective of even distribution of income and wealth

questions.explanation: Resource allocation, redistribution and stabilization are core public‑finance objectives; **deregulation policy** is not.

questions.question: The joint ventures operating in the Nigerian oil industry are between
questions.explanation: Joint ventures typically involve **NNPC and multinational oil companies**.

questions.question: Which of the following are the major disadvantages of a direct system of taxation?
questions.explanation: Direct taxes can **discourage work (I)**, are **difficult to assess and collect (II)**, and suffer from **assessment imperfections (III)**.

questions.question: Using the income table in figure Econ1993_IncomeComponents, calculate the net national income at factor cost (in billion naira).
questions.explanation: Domestic factor income: \(380 + 110 = 490\). Net factor income from abroad: \(20 - 10 = 10\). Gross national income at factor cost: \(490 + 10 = 500\). Subtract depreciation \(40\) to obtain **net national income**: \(500 - 40 = 460\).

questions.question: According to the income approach to national income measurement, the national income of a country is equal to

options.text: the value of all output produced in the country over the relevant period of time at market prices
the value of output at factor cost

questions.explanation: The income approach sums **factor incomes**, yielding national income measured at **factor cost**.

questions.question: The best index for international comparison of standards of living is
questions.explanation: For comparing countries, **per capita income** (national income divided by population) is most appropriate.

questions.question: The \(GDP\) of Nigeria will be greater than her \(GNP\) if

options.text: the value of goods and services imported into Nigeria is greater than the value of those exported
government expenditure is greater than foreign aid received
the value of goods and services produced by Nigerian business abroad is less than that of foreign businesses in Nigeria

questions.explanation: If income earned by foreigners in Nigeria exceeds income earned by Nigerians abroad, **net factor income from abroad is negative** and \(GDP > GNP\).

questions.question: Below equilibrium, the gap between aggregate demand and the full‑employment level of income is called the
questions.explanation: If planned spending at full‑employment income is **too low**, the shortfall is a **deflationary gap**.

questions.question:
Which of the following are advantages of Nigeria’s membership of ECOWAS? 
I. A greater opportunity for trade according to comparative cost advantage. 
II. A larger market for industries producing under conditions of decreasing cost. 
III. Competition for home‑based monopolistic firms.
questions.explanation: All three are **benefits of regional economic integration**.

questions.question: Comparative advantage implies that a country will specialize in producing the commodity

options.text: for which output per worker is lower than in other countries
for which output per worker is the same as in other countries

questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is based on **lower opportunity cost**, not necessarily higher absolute productivity.

questions.question: Devaluation is effective in improving the balance of payments when

options.text: demand for imports is price inelastic
demand for imports is interest inelastic
demand for exports is price elastic

questions.explanation: Devaluation improves the trade balance only if **foreign demand for exports is price elastic** (and usually if import demand is also elastic).

questions.question: In the output–time diagram in figure Econ1993_Unemployment_Waves, what type of unemployment is revealed by the dotted lines?
questions.explanation: The wavy path around a trend line depicts **business cycles**, whose associated joblessness is cyclical unemployment.

questions.question: From which of the following does Nigeria derive trade concessions?
questions.explanation: Preferential trade concessions for Nigeria historically came from the **European Economic Community (EEC)**.

questions.question: Tariffs on imports are meant to

options.text: prevent a country from becoming a dumping ground for foreign goods
increase the level of external dependency

questions.explanation: Import tariffs **protect domestic industries** and help avoid the economy becoming a dumping ground.

questions.question: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is important to developing countries because it

options.text: gives loans to member countries for legal proceedings
offers grants and aid for defence
offers loans to member countries for socio‑economic activities
offers grants and aid to finance luxury projects

questions.explanation: The IBRD (World Bank) provides **long‑term loans and development assistance** for socio‑economic projects.
